title: Albert Einstein
summary: Albert Einstein was a German-born theoretical physicist who is widely held to be one of the greatest and most influential scientists of all time.

data.Born: March 14, 1879, Ulm, Kingdom of Württemberg, German Empire
data.Died: April 18, 1955 (aged 76), Princeton, New Jersey, United States
data.Known for: Theory of relativity, Photoelectric effect, E=mc²

content.text: Albert Einstein (14 March 1879 – 18 April 1955) was a German-born theoretical physicist who is widely held to be one of the greatest and most influential scientists of all time. Best known for developing the theory of relativity, Einstein also made important contributions to quantum mechanics, and was thus a central figure in the revolutionary reshaping of the scientific understanding of nature that modern physics accomplished in the first decades of the twentieth century.

His mass–energy equivalence formula E = mc², which arises from relativity theory, has been called "the world's most famous equation". He received the 1921 Nobel Prize in Physics "for his services to theoretical physics, and especially for his discovery of the law of the photoelectric effect", a pivotal step in the development of quantum theory.

Einstein was born in the German Empire, but moved to Switzerland in 1895, forsaking his German citizenship (as a subject of the Kingdom of Württemberg) the following year. In 1897, at the age of 17, he enrolled in the mathematics and physics teaching diploma program at the Swiss Federal Polytechnic School in Zurich, graduating in 1900.

Einstein's scientific career is generally divided into two periods. In the first, he developed special and general relativity, while in the second, he became isolated from the mainstream of modern physics as he sought a unified field theory.

Einstein's special theory of relativity emerged from his attempts to reconcile the laws of mechanics with the laws of the electromagnetic field. He published his first paper on special relativity in 1905, showing that space and time are interwoven into a single continuum known as spacetime.
